outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: So You Need to Learn R

all_paragraphs: Last year I started teaching a six-week R programming course at a university, and I have another available online on Udemy, So You Need to Learn R. I thought long and hard about how to teach R. Here’s what I came up with.

I wanted a course that beginners could take. Most people learning R via a course aren’t computer scientists or experienced hackers, but doctoral students in the sciences, analysts who currently use Excel for their work, or those just starting to pursue career in data science. They might have basic coding experience, but maybe on shaky foundations.
(I did also want an experienced Python programmer to be able to come in and just focus on R syntax and what makes it different too, though.)

I knew I needed to cover basic programming concepts, like loops, data structures, and functions. But people learn R to do practical work with data, not to generally learn computer science. Thus, I really didn’t mention any theory, or talk about algorithm design, or anything like that. All of our examples and problems were about data (instead of how to write a sort function, for instance, like you might do in an intro C or Java class).

I was also determined, though, to incorporate actual programming and not just script writing. That distinction mostly came down to having students write their own functions. This teaches them about abstracting problems and thinking about corner cases, reusing code and building their own tools, as well as debugging.

I didn’t want to have any students finish my class who couldn’t write a simple function and apply it over their data. I say this because I’ve met many people who think they’ve learned R but can’t write a function, can’t index an array, and can’t use a loop. Those are fundamental to me: if you can’t do those tasks, why bother even using a programming language? So my courses focus on programming skills, not just script writing.

If students start with high-level tools, they’ll never understand what’s going on under the hood; and they’ll never be able to write customized solutions to trickier problems (that the high-level tools can’t handle). So I start basic, and build up their knowledge. We begin with vectors and spend a lot of time on them. Before we do aggregations on a data frame, we hand split a list (which a data frame actually is), compute the statistics, and then re-assemble it. That’s not a procedure you’re going to want to do every day; but it’s useful to have done it once.
Because of the focus on fundamental skills, I decided to stay very minimal with packages used.

We use reshape2 for some data transformations. This has the “melt” and “cast” workflow (for long and wide transformation, respectively) which is conceptually pretty simple, and shared with the more advanced data.table, should they ever learn that.

I use base graphics when possible, and introduce ggformula for more sophisticated plots. It’s a wrapper for ggplot2, but uses formula notation, which students have already seen in aggregations, and will see in model specification. I do mention other plot methods, like for decision trees.

In particular, I don’t teach anything from the tidyverse. I’m not a fan generally. But worse, the tidyverse works against most of my goals. It introduces a myriad of functions to learn, which try to elide the more basic operations in R. It actively discourages the use of subscripting and formulae — while instead encouraging pipes and the unusual syntax of ggplot2 instead.

Students who learn tidy seem to be good at quickly writing high-level scripts to handle certain common data tasks. But their core programming abilities often seem very weak. Many students in my classes had already tried learning R with the tidyverse, but couldn’t do things like index a vector! That’s not just a hole in their skills: it’s a hole in their mental process when they try to tackle problems.

We don’t just learn programming to tell a computer what to do: we learn programming to understand and approach problems in a different way; to become better thinkers. We can’t learn that approach if we don’t focus on the real tasks of programming, starting with what’s basic, and building up from there.

Of course, there’s a limit: R users shouldn’t worry about memory addresses, like you would in C. But they should worry about how a computer loops over the rows of a data frame as it executes an apply. It might not seem necessary for most problems: but when a harder problem arises, you need that more basic understanding so you can craft your own, custom solution.

I also discovered there’s limits on how much you want to build up to in an introductory course. The first term I taught, I concluded with a unit on data.table. What a mistake! The alternate syntax and little tricks of its use were too clever by half — the students were merely confused. They needed to solidify the basics more instead.

Ultimately, I teach R because I remember what a challenge it was for my colleagues in graduate school to learn it. They weren’t programmers. They weren’t computer nerds. So even though they were (very) smart, it was a struggle, because programming is a new way of thinking. I was lucky, since I’d been hobby programming for a while, and picking up R was comparatively easy. But for everyone else, there were few good resources, made for the kinds of people who need to learn R (early-career scientists, researchers, and analysts).

I think I’ve been able to fill that void with my courses. Not because I’m the best R programmer in the world, or because I have the most advanced understanding of R’s inner workings. But because I learned R like a lot of people did, on my own, and have been using it for more than a decade solving real problems. Even after all that, I still like R! It’s a weird mongrel of a language, and it’s not always easy to learn — but we can make it easier.

Jasper McChesney is a senior data analyst, with a background in natural science and data visualization. He has worked in non-profits, human-resources, and higher education. He currently teaches an R course at the University of Massachusetts, and on Udemy.
